importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Ostwall complex was abandoned by the Nazis in 1945, marking the end of its wartime military use and the beginning of its post-war history as a site of subcultural and ecological significance.
The London Tunnels are expected to open as a tourist attraction in 2028, linking their Cold War history to a modern resurgence in public interest in underground historical sites.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Ostwall complex was constructed during the 1930s and abandoned in 1945, placing it at the height of Nazi military planning and expansion, making it a significant historical artifact of wartime engineering and secrecy.

The London Tunnels were built during World War II, serving as a Cold War-era shelter and spy hub, and their transformation into a tourist site in the 2020s–2030s reflects a broader trend in historical preservation and experiential tourism.

keyTakeAways: The Ostwall, a 20-mile underground Nazi complex beneath the Polish village of Pniewo, was built for military use and abandoned in 1945, now serving as a dark tourism destination with 19 miles open to the public in the Międzyrzecz Fortified Region Museum.
The Passage of Commodus, an 180-foot Roman tunnel in Italy, is named after Emperor Commodus and believed to have been a site of an assassination attempt; it will open to the public this month.

The London Tunnels, a mile-long complex built during WWII, once housed the Special Operations Executive (SOE), a real-life inspiration for James Bond’s Q Branch, and will reopen in 2028 as a $149 million tourist attraction.
Kayaköy in Turkey, a ghost town abandoned over a century ago, now attracts visitors due to its eerie, overgrown state, serving as a reminder of historical conflicts like the Greco-Turkish war.
Babylon in Iraq, an ancient city of Mesopotamian importance, now has overgrown ruins and limited facilities, but remains a powerful symbol of ancient civilization and cultural heritage.
The Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum in West Virginia, once a site of overcrowding and poor medical care, is now a macabre tourist attraction offering tours that blend history with paranormal elements.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores a range of underground and abandoned historical sites around the world, focusing on the former Nazi Ostwall bunker complex beneath Poland’s Pniewo village — a 20-mile underground fortress abandoned in 1945 and now a dark tourism destination. It also highlights the Roman Passage of Commodus, believed to have been a site of an assassination attempt on Emperor Commodus, set to open to the public. The London Tunnels, built during WWII and used by the SOE, are being transformed into a $149 million tourist attraction with a planned opening in 2028. Other sites include the abandoned Turkish ghost town Kayaköy and ancient Babylon in Iraq, both serving as physical reminders of historical trauma and cultural legacy. The piece underscores a broader global trend in which abandoned, secretive, or traumatic sites are repurposed into experiential tourism, blending history, mystery, and public engagement.
title: Deep underground, the Nazis built a city for thousands of soldiers. Now it’s a tourist attraction
